title: Craig Casey
text:
Craig Casey (born 19 April 1999) is an Irish <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player for <a href="United%20Rugby%20Championship">United Rugby Championship</a> and <a href="European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup">European Rugby Champions Cup</a> side <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a>. Internationally, Casey made his senior debut for Ireland in 2021. He plays as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Scrum-half">scrum-half</a> and represents <a href="Shannon%20RFC">Shannon</a> in the <a href="All-Ireland%20League%20%28rugby%20union%29">All-Ireland League</a>.
Early life.
Born in <a href="Limerick">Limerick</a>, Casey captained <a href="Ardscoil%20R%C3%ADs%2C%20Limerick">Ardscoil Rís</a> to the semi-finals of the 2017 <a href="Munster%20Schools%20Rugby%20Senior%20Cup">Munster Schools Rugby Senior Cup</a>, and his performances saw him named in the Munster Schools top XV for 2017, as well as earning representation for Munster and Ireland at under-18 level. He is the nephew of former Shannon and Munster player <a href="Mossy%20Lawler">Mossy Lawler</a>.
Munster.
Casey joined the Munster academy ahead of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Munster%20Rugby%20season">2017–18</a> season, and won the "John McCarthy Award for Academy Player of the Year" in April 2019. Casey made his senior competitive debut for Munster in their 27–14 win against <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> in round 21 of the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Pro14">2018–19 Pro14</a> on 27 April 2019. Casey had been a late call-up to the bench for Munster after the starting scrum-half, <a href="Conor%20Murray">Conor Murray</a>, withdrew during the warm-up and <a href="Neil%20Cronin">Neil Cronin</a> was promoted to the starting XV. He joined the provinces senior squad ahead of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Munster%20Rugby%20season">2019–20</a> season on a development contract, before progressing to a full contract ahead of the 2020–21 season.
Casey made his first start for Munster in their 19–14 away win against <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> in round 8 of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Pro14">2019–20 Pro14</a> on 21 December 2019, and he made his European debut for the province in their 39–22 defeat away to French club <a href="Racing%2092">Racing 92</a> in round 5 of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup%20pool%20stage%23Pool%204">2019–20 Champions Cup</a> on 12 January 2020. One week later, Casey scored his first try for Munster in their 33–6 win against Welsh side <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a>, in what was the provinces final pool fixture of the 2019–20 Champions Cup. He signed a two-year contract extension with the province in February 2021. Casey's performances for Munster throughout the 2020–21 season saw him win the clubs "Young Player of the Year" award.
Ireland.
Casey had been in contention for selection for <a href="Ireland%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland under-20s</a> during 2018, but a series of injuries ruled him out. Having overcome his injury issues, Casey was named as vice-captain in the under-20s squad for the <a href="2019%20Six%20Nations%20Under%2020s%20Championship">2019 Six Nations Under 20s Championship</a>, and made three appearances, scoring two tries, during the tournament, which saw Ireland secure a grand slam victory for the first time since 2007. He was retained as vice-captain in the under-20s squad for the <a href="2019%20World%20Rugby%20Under%2020%20Championship">2019 World Rugby Under 20 Championship</a> when it was confirmed in May 2019.
When head coach <a href="Andy%20Farrell">Andy Farrell</a> announced the <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a> squad for their two remaining <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a> fixtures in October, delayed due to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, Casey was one of six players who, though not being called up to the squad, would train alongside it. Casey earned his first senior international call up in January 2021, when Andy Farrell announced the Ireland squad for the <a href="2021%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2021 Six Nations Championship</a>, and he made his senior debut against <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a> in round 3 on 27 February 2021, coming on as a replacement for <a href="Jamison%20Gibson-Park">Jamison Gibson-Park</a> in Ireland's 48–10 away win. Ireland captain <a href="Jonathan%20Sexton">Jonathan Sexton</a> remarked after the game that Casey's attitude reminded him of <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> legend <a href="Jonny%20Wilkinson">Jonny Wilkinson</a>.
Casey made his first start for Ireland in their <a href="2021%20July%20rugby%20union%20tests">mid-year test</a> against the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a> on 10 July 2021, which Ireland won 71–10, and featured off the bench in the 53–7 win against <a href="Argentina%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Argentina</a> in Ireland's final fixture of the <a href="2021%20end-of-year%20rugby%20union%20internationals">2021 Autumn Nations Series</a> on 21 November.
